headline: Ethereum Leads Broad Rally Across Asian Hours

sections.the_session:
• Ethereum surged 7.7% to reclaim $3,345, its strongest single-session performance in three weeks — a move that pulled the broader altcoin complex higher and compressed Bitcoin dominance below 57% for the first time since late November.

• Bitcoin pushed through $92,000 with relative ease during Hong Kong morning hours, finding buyers on each dip toward $91,500 — the kind of methodical bid-side support that suggests institutional accumulation rather than retail chasing.

• Solana's 4.8% gain to $139 came on elevated volume through Singapore afternoon trading, with on-chain data showing renewed activity in its DeFi protocols after weeks of dormancy.

• Total market capitalisation added $105 billion to reach $3.27 trillion, though the rally unfolded without the liquidation cascades that typically accompany moves of this magnitude — short interest had already been flushed in last week's volatility.
sections.the_session_title: ETH Outpaces Bitcoin as Risk Appetite Returns
sections.the_macro:
• The Federal Reserve's December meeting minutes, released during US hours, revealed growing comfort with the current rate trajectory — language that markets interpreted as confirmation that the hiking cycle remains firmly concluded, sending Treasury yields lower and risk assets higher.

• The dollar index slipped 0.4% overnight, its third consecutive session of weakness, providing a tailwind for crypto assets that have traded with increasing sensitivity to currency moves since the ETF approvals.

• US spot Bitcoin ETF flows turned positive again on Wednesday, with preliminary data suggesting approximately $380 million in net inflows — a reversal from the modest outflows that characterised the holiday-shortened trading week.

• European Central Bank officials maintained their hawkish rhetoric in Davos side meetings, but markets appear to have priced in the divergence between Fed and ECB policy paths, limiting the impact on risk sentiment.
sections.the_macro_title: Fed Minutes and Dollar Weakness Set the Table

east_asia.name: East Asia
east_asia.content:
• Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission confirmed it will begin accepting applications for spot Ethereum ETFs in Q1, building on the city's Bitcoin ETF framework — a move that positions the territory to capture institutional demand ahead of potential US approval.

• Japanese financial services giant SBI Holdings reported a 23% increase in crypto-related revenue for Q3, driven largely by its XRP custody and trading operations, signalling that institutional appetite in Japan remains robust despite the broader market's 2024 volatility.

• South Korea's Financial Services Commission proposed new guidelines requiring exchanges to hold 80% of customer assets in cold storage, up from the current 70% threshold — a tightening that follows last year's exchange failures elsewhere in the region.

• China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange published updated capital control guidance that explicitly addresses crypto-related outflows for the first time, though enforcement mechanisms remain unclear.

southeast_asia.name: Southeast Asia
southeast_asia.content:
• Singapore's Monetary Authority granted a Major Payment Institution licence to Blockchain.com, the firm's first full regulatory approval in Asia — a signal that the city-state continues to welcome established crypto firms even as it maintains strict retail protections.

• Thailand's SEC announced it will delay implementation of new crypto advertising restrictions until March, giving exchanges additional time to adjust marketing practices after industry pushback on the original January deadline.

• Vietnamese retail trading volumes on local P2P platforms reached a three-month high this week, with USDT pairs dominating activity as the dong faces renewed pressure against the dollar.

oceania.name: Oceania
oceania.content:
• Australia's Treasury released its long-awaited token mapping consultation paper, proposing a framework that would classify most crypto assets as financial products under existing law — a pragmatic approach that avoids creating bespoke crypto legislation.

• Iris Energy, the Australian-listed Bitcoin miner, reported its December hash rate reached 9.1 EH/s following the completion of its Texas facility expansion, making it one of the five largest publicly traded miners globally.

• The Australian dollar's 0.6% gain against the greenback overnight provided modest support for AUD-denominated crypto trading pairs, with local exchanges reporting a pickup in spot volume during Sydney afternoon hours.

image_keywords: Hong Kong skyline, golden sunset, Victoria Harbour, warm evening glow
